title: 107_hr3285
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal-Local Information Sharing Partnership Act of 2001" and grants authority to share grand jury information. Rule 6(e)(3)(C) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure is amended to allow sharing of grand jury information with law enforcement personnel of a State or political subdivision. Rule 6(e)(3)(C) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure is amended to allow sharing of grand jury information with State or political subdivision law enforcement personnel, with guidelines issued by the Attorney General to protect confidentiality. SEC. 3. AUTHORITY TO SHARE ELECTRONIC, WIRE, AND ORAL INTERCEPTION INFORMATION. Section 2517(6) of title 18, United States Code is amended to allow sharing of interception information with law enforcement personnel of a State or political subdivision. The amendment allows sharing interception information with state or political subdivision law enforcement personnel, with guidelines for confidentiality. SEC. 4. FOREIGN INTELLIGENCE INFORMATION. Section 203(d)(1) of the USA PATRIOT ACT is amended to allow sharing of information with state law enforcement personnel, removing the requirement for federal involvement. The USA PATRIOT ACT is amended to allow state law enforcement personnel to receive information without federal involvement. State or political subdivision personnel must use the information according to guidelines set by the Attorney General. The USA PATRIOT ACT is amended to allow state law enforcement personnel to receive information without federal involvement. Any chief executive officer or law enforcement personnel who receives information must use it according to guidelines set by the Attorney General to protect confidentiality. The USA PATRIOT ACT is amended to allow state law enforcement personnel to receive information for counterterrorism purposes without federal involvement, following guidelines set by the Attorney General to protect confidentiality. Section 626(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to allow the recipient of a consumer report to disclose the contents to state law enforcement personnel for official duties. This expands the scope of information sharing for law enforcement purposes. The amendment allows state law enforcement personnel to receive consumer report information for official duties, with guidelines issued by the Attorney General to protect confidentiality. SEC. 6. MULTILATERAL COOPERATION AGAINST TERRORISTS. Section 222(f) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow the Secretary of State to provide records related to visas or permits to law enforcement personnel of a State or political subdivision. The Secretary of State can provide records related to visas or permits to law enforcement personnel of a State or political subdivision if deemed necessary and appropriate. The Secretary of State may provide visa or permit records to law enforcement personnel of a State or political subdivision, with guidelines issued by the Attorney General for confidentiality protection. SEC. 7 amends the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act to include state law enforcement personnel in information acquisition. SEC. 8 pertains to information acquired from physical searches. SEC. 8 amends the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act to include state law enforcement personnel in information acquisition from physical searches. Section 444(j)(1)(B) of the General Education Provisions Act is amended to allow disclosure of education records to state law enforcement personnel, including the chief executive officer, for official duties. The amendment allows state law enforcement personnel, including the chief executive officer, to receive and use education records for official duties in accordance with guidelines. SEC. 10. INVESTIGATION AND PROSECUTION OF TERRORISM. Section 408(c)(1)(B) of the National Education Statistics Act of 1994 is amended to allow for the disclosure of reports, records, and information to law enforcement personnel for official duties. The National Education Statistics Act of 1994 allows disclosure of information to law enforcement personnel for official duties, with guidelines on how the information can be used.
